text: hey everybody it's love in a town and
today I wanted to teach you guys how I
make a model sheet or basically how I
draw character is over and over
consistently without them looking really
weird but first a quick shout out to
today's sponsor Amina Amina is an app
where you can find groups of people into
the stuff you're into
so obviously the anime art Amino is full
of people who love to draw and
appreciate anime arts a lot of you
probably know this already but I got
into drawing through anime so this is
something very close to home for me I
found the whole community to be very
warm and welcoming and there's tons of
stuff to do lots of chats and polls and
things to interact with speaking of
things you should interact with I
actually just put up a watercolor I did
recently exclusively up on Amino so if
you want to check that out please click
the link in the description my name on
Amino is Hayley Museum as you can see
thank you to me know for supporting my
channel okay so the inspiration for this
video is basically that I've been
noticing in my comic that my character
Blanchette goes off model quite a bit
now this is not an uncommon problem and
if you struggle with it please don't
feel bad because it's seriously
something that almost everybody has
trouble with from one time or another
especially if you're working on
animation or a comic it's just natural
that when you draw character a lot
there's going to be small things that
sort of change and if you're not being
cognizant of those things it's going to
happen more often than not so one of the
things I wanted to do first before I
started this turnaround was to get some
inspiration from some professional
sources now if you type in character
sheet into Google you're probably going
to find a lot of just random artists
posting their OCS
and when you can learn a lot from that I
find that if you search model sheet you
can find a lot of like Disney Pixar
professional different artists who've
done you know actual like production
work because it is a be more formal name
for what I'm looking for here
and that's I mean a model she is
basically so you don't go off model in
an animation it's a really good example
of how you can draw a simple turnaround
and it will make the end product of what
you're trying to make significantly
better this is also why sometimes
characters will go off model for an
entire episode because sometimes
episodes are animated in different
studios who have different model sheets
this can happen in modern shows as well
as older shows and it's kind of an
interesting phenomenon because they'll
be butwe consistent within this episode
but they'll be off model from other
episodes and it seems kind of strange
that that would happen in the first
place I just wonder why they don't send
each other all the same model sheet but
anyway the key things that you want to
do when you're drawing this kind of
turnaround is you want to make sure that
you're doing enough different angles now
in the past I've done turnarounds on
this channel and usually all I do is the
front view the side view and the back
view and I really thought that that was
good enough but I'm starting to realize
the importance of having those more
subtle angles in here as well so I'm
going to try to do two bonus angles
apart from my standard three because I
think it will add a lot better
understanding of the sort of planchette
in 3d space rather than thinking about
her in 2d and that is one of the best
ways you can make your characters
consistent thinking about them as a 3d
shape that has actual you know weight
and consequences in physics is a great
way to make sure that they're not going
off model other things that I try to
consider is how are their proportions
sort of relate to each other so one of
the things that I've been doing ever
since the start is trying to make sure
that her sleeves are the same rough size
as her actual like top it just makes it
so that it doesn't get like crazy off
model because I know that those things
should be roughly the same size and then
some other things I try to do I try to
make sure that her skirt is the same
width as the brim of her hat one of the
things I didn't have one
these sort of rough markers by how big
or small it should be is her eyes and
her other facial proportions and that is
one of the things I've had the most
trouble with consequently and you'll see
me drawing a lot of different lines in
between each of these drawings luckily
because we're in the sketch phase we can
do as many lines as we want every time I
thought I could do it by eyeballing it I
quickly realized that it's just much
better to draw a line it's surprisingly
hard to get things exactly where they
need to be and especially when you're
doing these more subtle turns things can
look a little bit different I found
myself wanting to warp things towards
the camera it's just sort of a habit
I've gotten hit into and for a model
sheet that's definitely not something I
wanted to be doing so I found myself
consistently correcting and trying to
make sure that things were as in line as
they possibly could be there were a few
places where I had a particular struggle
trying to imagine them in 3d space her
hat is one of those for sure for me
because I always want the hat to be
separated away from the brim invisible
that's kind of a cartoon cheating out
kind of thing that I often do so I found
myself pushing the tip of the hat away
even when it would make sense for it to
be touching the brim or at least to
appear to be touching or overlapping
based on the angle I wanted to sort of
push it away just so that would have a
pedal it better silhouette and you can
do that it just depends on if that's
something you're willing to
stylistically commit to or not because
if that's not what you want to do in
your animation or your comic then it's
not what you should do in your model
sheets I should also say and I don't
know if this is obvious or not but just
in case it's not there are a lot of
other things that you should draw
alongside your model sheet when it comes
to developing a character for some type
of media one of the things that I found
the most interesting and fun when I was
looking up sort of research on the
professional versions of these is that
there's a lot of sheets of just the
characters making different faces and I
think that might actually be really
helpful with the consistency as well
because characters having a signature
angry face or a signal
you're a suspicious face or something
like that
is something that can really add a lot
of life to them and also make them seem
a lot more real I think a lot of people
in real life have specific faces that
they fall into under similar emotional
states or situations and so it makes a
lot of sense for your characters to also
have those things it also just make
things a lot easier if you're searching
for ways to make them a moat if you have
a whole sheet of different faces that
you wanted them to make in your story
you can always just cross-reference that
and try to find the right expression for
the job oftentimes I sort of realized
that I'm giving my character's
mannerisms without even meaning to
certain characters just hold themselves
a specific way but if that's something
that you struggle with having a sheet to
reference might really help you out so
definitely give it a try when you're
posting a character on your character
sheet I would say resist giving them a
tee pose unless there's a really
important reason for it I think having
them rest in a sort of normal
comfortable stance for what would fit
their personality and how you expect to
see them the most is probably the best
as long as it's not covering up too much
of their design or their outfit
obviously you want all of that to be
seen as clearly as possible so for
example on planchette I did try to have
her arms set in a way where we can
clearly see her sleeves and she's not
deforming her skirt too much I thought
it suited her personality okay but most
importantly it was a way for her to
stand semi comfortably without sort of
morphing her outfit or covering up too
much of it which is obviously really
important when you're making yourself
reference images and that's basically
what this is you're basically creating
yourself reference images so that in the
future of your comic or your book or
whatever you're trying to make that you
have a little helping hand to keep you
on model you should also be careful
though if you're the type to lean more
towards being a perfectionist rather
than not I would say you do have to be
careful not to get too strict about your
character staying on model there's going
to be some scenes where you have to
something a little bit or change
something a little bit and that's
totally okay if you make a big change
that you want to keep you can just add
that to your model sheet and just try to
keep it consistent from that point
forward for example there is something
that I've done with flinch at that at
the start it really wasn't present at
the beginning of my design for her I had
her have very pale orange eyes now I
like this for a while but I started to
realize how the story continued and I
added more complex backgrounds and
things like that I started to realize
that she was getting really washed out
especially because she's the only
character who only has a black and white
dress of the main cast so she was having
trouble sort of popping with the other
girls around her so I decided to add a
little more intensity that I would add a
bright red gradient over her orange eyes
and it became something that I really
really liked the look of so rather than
just being a experiment I decided to
make it part of her character
colorization form now on now I'm not -
the colouring stage quite yet the inking
took forever but you'll see in just a
moment how I keep the colors consistent
as well because you do not want a mood
ring character whose colors change
constantly unless that really is part of
their character that might actually be
quite interesting but if that's not
canonically part of who they are you
want to keep things consistent on the
color scale as well but before I can
even get into that we've got to continue
inking all of these different sides of
planchette now I have the most
difficulty with the profile probably I
think for whatever reason it was just
looking really stiff and really strange
I was having a lot of trouble keeping
everything where it belongs
though once I did get her facial
features figured out on her profile shot
I realized that this is one of the
things that I needed the model sheet for
the most when Chet's face changes a lot
in profile because I don't draw her in
Easter
profile that often so when I do I'm
pretty much always rusty at it I'm
really going to like having something to
reference back on when I'm having
trouble placing her mouth and her nose
where it looks like it belongs sometimes
you really just need to see the other
angles of her face to realize where
everything is supposed to go hopefully
you'll find that with your characters as
well that it just helps clear some stuff
up for you it can be really hard to do
all of this in your head especially
without any type of referencing that
you've drawn previously so if you take
your time and be patient with yourself
while you're making the model sheet
it'll probably save you a lot of time
and trouble in the future and don't get
me wrong I realized that the small sheet
is not perfect there are a lot of places
where if she sort of warped a little bit
but still it's a big improvement to
trying to do this straight out of my
head even with me mistakes
I'm also going to show you in just a
second how you can check for mistakes on
this if you're having trouble telling if
there's a problem because obviously you
know if this is something that you've
been struggling with already the actual
drawing of the model sheet is also going
to be hard unfortunately like so many
things that are pretty much it's it's
it's all difficult and it's in one way
or another there were a lot of things
that I had to continually keep editing
and changing especially her skirt I
really hadn't thought about the
logistics of it I always sort of pushed
her skirt down a little bit so that she
didn't look lewd or anything I just had
to give her bloomers from now on though
so I don't have to worry about that as
much and I did realize that her skirt
should be sort of tilted up if it's
tilted down the way it is in the front
facing picture so I per grudgingly did
that on the back angles where you can
mostly just see her back so here's a way
to check to see how well your turnaround
went basically just make a gif with your
character rotating it's pretty cool
effect I quite like how it looks though
it does reveal to me a few places where
she's not quite right but overall it was
close enough for me I still feel like
it's gonna be really useful so
instead of doing anymore edits at this
point I decided to get started on the
color so I highly recommend that you do
some experimentation if this is the
first time that you're really committing
to a color palette for your character
color palettes can be hugely helpful to
make sure that your character looks the
same even if you are having an off model
day as long as they have the same color
palette you're probably going to get
away with it relatively well but if your
colors are going off off model I guess
you could still say um it's going to
mess things up a lot and make it look a
lot more sort of amateur I guess the way
that I stay with the same colors always
is at least on Photoshop I use this
little plugin called cool eros or
Caloris and basically you can just drag
down and make palettes out of any colors
that you're using another way that you
can do this in any program basically is
just to have a tiny image of your
character in previous panels or previous
frames or whatever and just eyedropper
tool wherever you need to pick up the
color if you can try to make swatches
because it will save you a lot of time
rather than you know I dropping a JPEG
every single time and also be careful if
you're using multiple different screens
make sure that your screen is color
calibrated because that can mess you up
as well and really confuse you but that
is the benefit of saving a swatch rather
than doing it by eye because even if
you're on I really messed up monitor
you're going to keep it at least
consistent so that's basically the
finished product I'm still shading here
and there in the footage but I hope this
was helpful to you guys it's kind of a
more straightforward tutorial video than
I usually do I just really wanted to
make a model sheet for my character and
hopefully teach you guys how you can do
that for your characters as well thank
you so much for watching till the end
